name: places/ChIJge57gAxbwokRu1OLj5KvwKw
formattedAddress: 100 Pearl St, New York, NY 10004, USA
adrFormatAddress: 100 Pearl St, New York, NY 10004, USA

originalText.text: Found this place by complete accident while looking for a different restaurant (that we never found) so what a life saver for this food court to be here! There's a ton of different options in here and honestly all of them sound good. There's plenty of seating, and it's clean and attractive. The bathroom situation was not desirable as you have to access it through a maze of basement hallways and then the women's room was locked while the men's room wasn't :'(

originalText.text: This place looked absolutely amazing; although, I didn't get to experience the Wall Street crowd. I bet it is a nightmare during lunchtime. The restrooms are down a breeze way in the basement area. I had to take the stairs to get there, considering the elevator wasn't for the public.

text.text: This place looked absolutely amazing; although, I didn't get to experience the Wall Street crowd. I bet it is a nightmare during lunchtime. The restrooms are down a breeze way in the basement area. I had to take the stairs to get there, considering the elevator wasn't for the public.

originalText.text: It's an OK food hall. It has the feel of a mall food court, And I was looking for coffee and breakfast but the coffee and pastry shop had recently closed. There are better food halls in Manhattan, the nearby Tin at Pier 17 is much better. Again, not awful but there are better places. Also, the prices seemed high for lower Manhattan.

text.text: It's an OK food hall. It has the feel of a mall food court, And I was looking for coffee and breakfast but the coffee and pastry shop had recently closed. There are better food halls in Manhattan, the nearby Tin at Pier 17 is much better. Again, not awful but there are better places. Also, the prices seemed high for lower Manhattan.

originalText.text:
This review is for Senshi Ramen inside Urbanspace.

Huge rip off. $21 for a bowl of bad ramen.
I know it's FiDi + inflation but the price is outrageous for tasteless ramen.

I ordered the Signature Black Garlic & spicy (+$1) but only the chashu was spicy, everything else lacked in flavor. $2 for an egg add on? It should be included.

A friend asked for no scallions and of course they put scallions.
They said they would help bring the food to our table but they screamed and shouted our order # until we walked up there to grab our food.

The Karaage appetizer was 5 chicken nuggets for $11 with inconsistent batter. Also overpriced but was the better tasting part of the meal and that's not saying much.

2 bowls of ramen, 1 app, 2 drinks, w/ tip cost $70.

I would 1000% skip this spot in Urbanspace. Highly recommend eating something else.

originalText.text:
I'm not going as far as to claim this is a hidden gem when Katsu Katsu literally in the middle of a bustling food court in the Financial District, but I do think it's a bit under the radar given that it's literally Michelin rated; how many of the divey teriyaki chicken and cheese fries stands in your food courts can say that? My palate isn't sophisticated enough to really get into whether specific food is worthy of that type of accolade (besides this, I've been to a restaurant in San Juan that had a Michelin rating  - 1919 in Condado - and I remember more about the presentation of the dishes and the black horse lamp/statute right outside than the taste of the food) but I can say that it's the best of the options in Urban Space, and there's some legit competition here.

This was initially a recommendation by one of my chums a few months ago. I've been coming to Urban Space since it opened last summer and have regularly frequented the Playa Bowls (way less depressing than the one down the street at One New York Plaza), the Puerto Rican place and the prior pizza establishment. All perfectly fine, depending on your mood, but Katsu didn't catch my eye for whatever reason. It's very tasty, and not like the "normal" curry you expect with Indian food (which was my mistaken impression) - it's a sweeter curry and for me at least far preferable. I don't hate Indian food, but I need to be in the mood for it, which only happens every six months or so. This type of curry? I could eat on at least a weekly basis, and sometimes I have. There's enough of the curry provided that it should be able to soak up not only the slices of chicken, but the scoop of accompanying rice as well (I can do without the thin strands of radishes or whatever is also included). The chicken is super flavorful as well, and is prepared in a panko-style, which is obviously still fried but doesn't feel as naughty as making a KFC run.

The portion is very decent and filling; I've had this for lunch around 1 and literally not been hungry for the rest of the day. I think the price point is a LITTLE high even given the quality and portion - with tip, this runs you a little over $20, when it should really be closer to $17ish in my opinion for a quicker sit-down meal - but it's certainly not as egregious as some other places in the neighborhood. The wait time can also be all over the place, depending on the staff and the number of customers. I've had a handful of instances where I've ordered and gotten my food within 30 seconds. Perfect. I've also had occasions where it's taken 10 minutes or so. If time is a concern, I'd go on a Friday when the crowd has thinned out for the weekend (this spot is a little too far removed from the tourist areas to really have much of a demographic beyond nearby office workers).

Urban Space in general has been a positive. It's a cool spot with a decent amount of comfortable seating (though it can get crowded and a little difficult to find a spot right at the height of lunch), with varied, above average options. Katsu Katsu is at the head of the pack.
